title: Are courses free on coursera.org? - Quora

response.answer_text: Many of Coursera’s courses are still free. Edit (March 2020) - update fourth category to “Coursera Plus,” update the cost-benefit analysis to reflect new pricing scheme Edit (August 2017) - added a fourth category of Coursera’s offerings These include the very popular Machine Learning and Learning How to Learn courses, which have taught millions of students to date and will likely teach millions more for free. But there are also many courses that aren’t free, as you’re aware (but even these you can get for free depending on your circumstances—see below). Since this question comes up quite often, I’ve put together a small outline that describes the differences between t̶h̶r̶e̶e̶ four main categories of Coursera’s offerings and their respective pricing plans: Free coursesGain access to all of the course materials. Pay nothing for these courses unless you want a certificate.Limited free coursesGain access to most of the course materials; some materials like quizzes, assignments, exams might not be available. Only pay if you want full access and/or a certificate.SpecializationsA series of courses that usually ends in a capstone project that teaches you a subject in great depth, think of this as a mini-degree. Finishing one means you’ll likely (if you mastered the topics) come away with employable skills and knowledge. This one’s a bit complicated since Coursera seems to tinker with new ideas and experiments, but in general, you have:Fixed fee: pay a set price for each course (e.g. $79/course) or purchase the entire specialization as a set from the get-go (usually with a x% discount)Monthly fee: pay a monthly fee that gives you access to the entire specialization as long as you’re subscribed. You can sign up for a free 7-day trial, which gives you access to everything except the capstone. In theory, you can cram an entire specialization into 7 days and pay to gain access to the capstone, but I’m not sure how well that would fly in practice.Unlimited Annual Access (Coursera Plus)Coursera now has an unlimited plan available. Previously, this was priced at $49/mo. The monthly is no more. Instead, we now have Coursera Plus, which grants unlimited access to Coursera (including Specializations) $399/year. That’s quite a savings over the old monthly plan, which would have cost $588/year!Quick Cost-Benefit Analysis The monthly fee options (3b) and (4) are really only worth it if you have time to double up on courses. Since most courses take about 8–12 weeks to complete, you end up paying between $68 and $92 per course using the monthly fee option if you only take one course at a time (this applies to most people). Unless you’re constantly moving through courses or you’re taking multiple at a time, you might better served paying the $79 to own a single course outright. Getting cost information for courses OpenCourser (*plug- this is my site) gathers information on pricing for online courses that makes it easier to compare key information like pricing on a course. It’s frequently updated. You can also get pricing information straight from the source by visiting each course page on Coursera separately. To find out if a course you’re interested in is free, semi-free, or paid, look for visual cues from the “enroll” buttons on the site (note: you may need to login first to see these differences):  In this image, the button on the left shows a monthly fee trial for a paid specialization (Type 3b). The button on the right is a free course (Type 1) that you can audit in its entirety without charge. Financial Aid Coursera also offers need-based financial aid, which can offset most or all of your costs for a paid course or specialization. If you think you qualify, try submitting an application. It takes about 10–15 minutes to fill one out during which you’ll be asked to provide identifying information and details (e.g. income) that let Coursera determine your eligibility. If you find this answer helpful, please follow and check out OpenCourser, a site that helps learners find online courses.

There are 3 types of paid and unpaid courses on Coursera: Type 1 : courses that come with Full-Course, no certificate options: this is the majority of the courses on Coursera, believe it or not, they are the majority. For these courses, you can choose to pay and get the certificate, or just do the full course for free while still enjoying all the experience.Type 2 : the supposedly 'premium' paid courses. For these courses, they don't provide full experience if you choose to do it for free. Meaning, you can still have access to everything, except the ability to submit the assignments for feedbacks. These courses hence, have 2 options: Audit Only (free + no access to assignments) and certificate (full experience + certificate). What happens if you really want those courses, but cannot pay? Financial aid is available, and it's very generous (they allow a maximum of 1 course at a time).Type 3 : courses that are purely for learning, meaning, totally free, there are no certificates offered, even if you want to pay, and there are no restrictions to the course experience. These courses are usually from Stanford and Princeton.Personally, I think the implication of this is that we have to exercise greater discretion when it comes to choosing courses. If you're expecting learning on Coursera to be a free buffet party, then you definitely should only focus on Type 1 courses. I think it is pointless to go in the forums of Type 2 courses and complain why they are not free and not the same as the Type 1 courses. We should understand that those courses take a very large amount of effort and money to create, so either they are chargeable, or they don't exist at all. Also, we should remember that, there's always a large number of Type 1 and also a small number of Type 3 courses for people who purely love learning and don't need the certificates. Hope it helps you…….
